abstract.p: How to combat slime mold growing on tree trunks, plants and turf described (S)

block.p: Yellow, gray or orange slime mold growing in wet, decaying organic matter looks alarming, but just shovel it up and discard it. It rarely harms plants on which it grows. On tree trunks or woody stems or in turf, wash off with a strong stream of water.
More damaging are bagworms, which tie cocoons on juniper or arborvitae and on deciduous trees like birch, elm and willow. Pick and destroy their curious two-inch-long brown bag houses.

Continue deadheading to extend bloom of perennials like Helenium and Heliopsis. Don't let border phlox (Phlox paniculata) go to seed: resulting plants may not be true to color. Collect and save seed of heirloom vegetables and annuals.
